newsitem.title: GERMANY: German Bunds in better shape, hope to consolidate.
newsitem.headline: German Bunds in better shape, hope to consolidate.

text.p: German Bunds hauled themselves back up in early Friday trade, recovering slightly from a bruising sell-off in the past two sessions.
Traders said key technical support were close at hand, but since the levels were violated late on Thursday, their strength may well not hold if another selling bout emerges.
First support comes in the 100.80/83 region for the June contract, where a Fibonacci retracement level combines with a congestion area.
By 0646 GMT, the future was trading comfortably above this level at 100.88, up 15 basis points on the day.
Charles Diebel, senior fixed income analyst at Technical Data in London, said the recent weakness in Bunds stemmed from growing doubts about the strength of Europe's planned single currency.
"What we are seeing here is a growing general consensus that Germany is just not going to make the three perecnt deficit target," he said.

He said this had prompted some investors to move down the yield curve into shorter-dated maturities, and was encouraging more international convergence plays between German and European high-yield markets.
Cash Bunds, however, have held up well in the storm of selling which has hit futures in the past few days.
The cash July 2007 benchmark was trading at 100.68 for a bid yield of 5.902 percent by 0714 GMT.
Some analysts said they thought investors had been hedging underlying cash positions by selling futures, adding to the weakness already instilled by domestic budget concerns.
For this session, analysts said an absence of key economic data and the prospect of a long weekend in Britain should enable the market to calm down a little as positions are squared for the week.

"I would expected the market will range trade today with a slightly firmer bias," said Diebel. "People in London will be squaring up before the long weekend and I should think we'll see some bids coming through there to cover shorts."
Analysts at DMG futures and options in Frankfurt said that after Bunds made a positive early move above the 100.85 level, the chances for a bounce up to the 101.00 to 101.10 region had improved.
But any rally beyond 101.15/25 was unlikely, analysts said.
